summary: Officer K (Ryan Gosling), a new blade runner for the Los Angeles Police Department, unearths a long-buried secret that has the potential to plunge what's left of society into chaos. His discovery leads him on a quest to find Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford), a former blade runner who's been missing for 30 years.

reviews.content: Blade Runner 2049 is not only a visual masterpiece, but the greatest looking movie of all time. Ryan Gosling portrays K very well, slowly progressing from a stone-cold killer to a more unstable man questioning his entire reality. Harrison Ford still has  great charisma in this film, and you can clearly tell that he was excited to return to his character once more, unlike in The Force Awakens.
Best looking movie to have ever been produced, with masterfully crafted soundtrack, wonderfully created and acted characters. Simply a masterpiece.
I'm Ryan Gosling (he is literally me)

One of the most seamless marriages of cinematography, narrative, and GFX. A gorgeously crafted movie that has pioneered the conventions of cinematography accompanied by its immsersive and droning soundscape, thereby successfully reserving its spot in the pantheon of groundbreaking films. The brutalist architecture, overwhelming landscapes that swallow characters, contrasting color palettes like drowning irradiated Los Angelinos in a bright orange hue, these define the film and qualify it as an everlasting experience through a myriad of visual beauty. However, the story is dragged out and can seem overly long, but each shot is masterfully carried out, and that deserves the viewing and praise. I am forever perplexed how this marvel flunked at the box office. Its soundscape and cinematography surely were elevated in the experience.

This film is really good. The visuals and cinematography are absolutely gorgeous. The acting is great, Ryan Gosling does a good job as the silent & brooding protagonist. The plot is good although it does drag on in places and can be a little hard to follow. Definitely worth watching if you're into futuristic sci-fi or just for the visuals alone.

Set 30 years after the original, ‘Blade Runner 2049' follows LAPD "blade runner" Officer K (Ryan Gosling) as he uncovers a secret that could cause chaos in his dystopian society. At nearly 3 hours long, you're taken on a lengthy investigation to discover the origins of said secret, yet the movie keeps you engaged and interested through its entire runtime. The cast all deliver great performances, specifically Gosling and Jared Leto (who plays, you guessed it, a creepy guy). The stunning scenery and set design fully immerse you in this futuristic world, and the music perfectly complements every scene it's utilized in. This film also has some of the best cinematography I've ever seen, and from a visual standpoint, is truly a work of art. While I'm admittedly not a fan of the original, I enjoyed this sequel much more. A riveting sci-fi mystery (you could even call it a detective story) with some gorgeous camerawork and an unexpected twist or two, ‘Blade Runner 2049' is more than worth your time and will linger in your mind long after the credits roll. 
(Side note: I would recommend watching the original first, as you'll probably understand and enjoy this one more.)
Simply put, Blade Runner 2047 is the best movie ever made.

I really enjoyed this movie. I wish I could have seen it sooner, I watched it for the first time 2/11/23. The movie goes through so many highs and lows for our main character while telling a beautifully crafted story. The movie has themes that are eerily similar to what people can experience in real life. Like the feelings of searching for a purpose, truly feeling alone, struggling to know what to believe in, feeling like a slave, being trapped, losing a loved one, and feeling like your life is meaningless. I know a lot of movies can show these emotions and feelings, but the way this movie goes about it is special. I also think this is Ryan Gosling best work I have seen. The way he portrays this character really makes you really feel connected with him and his journey. He also somehow brings this emptiness and sadness that I have never seen in a character. The movie is also a cinematography masterpiece. It has beautiful and breathtaking visuals with equally dark and scary visuals. You really feel like this dystopian future is really not that far fetched and you could be looking at it. I would recommend this movie to anyone who is struggling with trauma or depression. You can really relate to this movie which can help cope with those emotions but it also could be a trigger. This movie does have a heavy emotional impact. I would also recommend this movie to anyone else over 18+. There is some hard concept to grasp and a fair amount of gore, violence, and nudity. After watching this film for the first time I knew it was already one of my favorite films. I would highly recommend giving it a watch.

The rare sequel that improves upon the original, Blade Runner 2049 balances stunning visuals with a darkly philosophical narrative that manages to keep you completely engaged for the entire nearly 3-hour runtime.

I can confidently say that Blade Runner 2049 is a triumph of filmmaking. The film dares to be ambiguous, but ambiguity is a good fit with its reflective nature. On its own merits, it is a very strong film; as a sequel, it's nothing short of brilliant.

The performances of Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford are outstanding and their onscreen chemistry suggests an evolution of masculinity within the films. The world building is immaculate, full of true wonder, and keeps you under its spell all the way to the very end. In some ways, it even surpasses the original.

The story is a methodically structured puzzle, solved through slow but persistent drips of revelation. The director, Denis Villeneuve, achieves a cerebral and even touching picture, while also accomplishing an uncommonly sublime production, marks Blade Runner 2049 as a landmark in the science-fiction genre.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to all hedy science-fiction fans, as it is a new chapter, a triumph, and a cinematic miracle. A must-watch for any cinephile.
This film is absolutely in my top five movies, I will say it's not for everyone with it's slow pacing but if you are a fan of sci-fi then this movie is a must watch

To create a sequel to an acknowledged masterpiece is brought with danger. Villeneuve capably honors the original and blends in further world building, history and breadth. Masterful cinematography with excellent sound engineering. I am not a Gossling fan, but he played the new Blade Runner well. Ford is an indulgent addition, though unnecessary, it does not take away. Those that believe this film is better than its forefather are those who argue the Chicken and egg conundrum. This film could not exist without the original. As such I was left with the question "WHY" after the films conclusion. The story it tells is not integral, as such, it lacks a real depth which ultimately takes away a bit of the cyber shine.

Blade Runner 2049 Review
	In Blade Runner 2049 a new Blade Runner who goes by K discovers a secret which leads him to go searching for former Blade Runner Rick Deckard. 
Blade Runner 2049 is like Blade Runner in which it's a futuristic world where it seems like it's night all the time and raining all the time. The protagonist in Blade Runner 2049 Agent K is like the protagonist in Blade Runner Rick Deckard. He gets frustrated a lot because it's difficult for him to solve a puzzle as a cop. The character Luv in Blade Runner 2049 is like the character Roy because she wants to be more human, only she tries to achieve her goal by doing evil. 
The world created in Blade Runner 2049 is fascinating because, like the first Blade Runner it's always night and raining. The director has his own style by making it a world that's snowy and cloudy as well. Most of the action takes place indoors or outdoors of the futuristic world. There's action when the bad guys capture Rick, when Agent K finds him in a city or town. Lighting is used to highlight the action.  For example, an orange lighting is seen when he finds Rick.   It is revealed that for all these years Rick has been spending time in an abandoned casino.
	The casino looks very futuristic and techno like. It shows holograms of Elvis Presley, Frank Sinatra, and Marilyn Monroe. The holograms appear in a place that looks like a bar and another place that looks like a restaurant. The holograms make sounds which is a little disturbing and this happens when K and Rick are fighting.
	Blade Runner 2049 is worth seeing because it's brilliant with its visuals and script.
a fucking masterpiece

On many levels, Villeneuve's film is superior to Scott's original. It is more beautiful, better paced, even better acted. I loved it.
And it is more clever. Luv literally crushes K's Joi, a wonderful metaphor: K sacrifices his joy (and his life) to help Deckard meet his daughter (the kind of love K can never experience).
And yet, K's quest is not the equal of Roy Batty's in the original. We are left with a low-stakes reason for watching. K is not Parsifal, and his sacrifice is not understandable other than as a personal gesture. 
Had Villeneuve found a way to elevate rather than diminish K's sacrifice, his film would endure.

It is unfortunate that this movie didn't break the box office but it is one of the better if not best science fiction movie made by Denis Villeneuve. His attention to detail is what makes this such a worth while movie. The critics that complain about the pacing don't appreciate that good art takes time to ingest. I found myself rewinding scenes just take it all in. I wonder what master pieces we would have if Mr. Villeneuve was allowed to touch Star Wars or Star Trek. If this movie was longer I would still watch it. It is one of those movies you do not want to end because you are absorbed by it and are submerged in its creative universe. The acting was perfect, casting was perfect, dialogue on point, scenes and cgi were perfection and action sequences leaves you at the edge of your seat and finally the story telling was delicious. Bravo!

Blade Runner 2049 is a 21st century classic. It's better than its predecessor in terms of being more complex while also more accessible. The visuals and design are amazing. Blade Runner 2049 is long and meditative, aiming to immerse the audience in its world and mythos much more than it tries to deliver on audience expectations. That means not every character feels utilized to their full potential, and some plot threads can feel overly long while others were half-baked. But it may also be one of the film's biggest strengths as it decides to owe nothing to anything but itself and its predecessor, resulting in a confident, singular vision. Does that make for a movie everyone flocks to the movie theatre to see? No, and it was the same case for the first film. However, it does end up being easy to love for its target audience, and I expect it to stand the test of time.

One of those movies, that completely immerses you in it‘s world. Maybe the slow pacing isn‘t for everyone. This is a movie, that doesn‘t need to fill every second with action and instead lets you dwell on the thoughts that have been invoked by the amazing story and the beautiful imagery. Denis Villeuneuve proves once again, why he is one of the best directors (if not the best director) currently crafting movies.

Blade Runner 2049 is a movie I recommend to anyone that wants to invest their time watching a good movie. It is not a traditional fast-paced science fiction movie. It is a detective movie, with a slow pace in the first part of it, but also with a jaw-dropping knot and conclusion. I rate it five stars.
The story of the movie is written masterfully. The secret of the naturally born replicant unveils smoothly. As the audience follows Officer K, they learn the different facts about the case. When they reach the end, the parts of the case merge to deliver a plot twist that will leave the audience speechless. The plot of Blade Runner 2049 is story writing at its finest. 
The film will not only entertain the audience, but it will also make them think and feel. More relevant than its story or technical aspects, the strongest quality of the movie is its thought-provoking message. The audience will not only enjoy a great movie, but they will also ponder about their own lives.
Cinematography: Masterpiece. Storytelling: Masterpiece. Everything: Masterpiece.

A solid sequel to Blade Runner.  Perhaps a little too long but interesting.  Ryan Gosling is excellent and it's nice to see Harrison Ford in the role again.
A bit boring but ok for a lazy Sunday evening.

Beautiful, melancholy, introspective, and thought provoking. Incredible cinematography, countless scenes in this movie are striking masterpieces of filmography, particularly the car on the beach scene near the end. The movie creates powerful questions that make the viewer question what they define humanity as- what does it mean to be human? In what ways are humans and replicants different? Where do you draw the line? This movie leaves you thinking for days and weeks after. If you haven't read the book "Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?" or seen the first movie, you may need to read up on some background after. But I think this movie is enjoyable even without understanding the background. My only regret is that I didn't see the movie in theaters. The only big turnoffs I can point out to potential viewers are the length and the fact the movie is a bit of a slow burn. But if you can handle digging into the depths of your own mind to try to answer the most foundational questions defining humanity, then I can't recommend Blade Runner 2049 enough!
Personally loved it. Professionally, a masterclass film. Great director, actors did a very good job and cinematography was top-notch. Very difficult to beat a film like this one. Very underrated.

The very essence of Style over Substance. 
Visually gorgeous. Good acting, mostly.  Harrison Ford almost looked like he cared, a couple of times.  But that's all of the plusses. 
The writers were obviously more concerned with being clever, unpredictable, and mysterious than concerned about telling a cohesive story in a movie length situation.

From the almost complete lack of an identifiable antagonist (Leto's cartoonish character? Luv? Who is the antagonist that drives the conflict with the protagonist that provides narrative push? No one.), a protagonist that ends up not mattering one whit, a silly "plot twist/shocking reveal" focused story that significantly reduces any re-watchability, a relationship story in Joi and K that's just zeroed out suddenly in such a way that clearly demonstrates that it wasn't very important (yet somehow took up a vast amount of screen time early in the film), a soundtrack that was perfectly OK Hans Zimmer but had only one recognizable song, one moment where the audience felt it and THAT one part was from the original movie's Vangelis soundtrack. People certainly won't be listening to this generic Zimmer score 30 years from now like they still listen to Vangelis original Blade Runner soundtrack.

And the additional frustration of being told "you just don't get it" and "oh, you're part of the attention deficit audience problem".  No, I got it fine, it's not exactly Fellini. It's just poorly written. 

As someone who was looking forward to this movie and is a fan of the original, it was profoundly disappointing in all areas other than visual extravagance and good acting.
Achieving exactly what the first one did. Blade Runner 2049 expands on the franchise and still blows us away with its visual effects in a modern generation.

Decent story but by two hours in, I was seeking a quick death. An overly complex plot with scenes that carry on and on and on. A sequel that honors the original is uncommon.  A sequel that rivals it is even rarer.  Considering this choice is between Scott's story and highly influential world creation (loosely from the Philip K Dick novel) vs Villeneuve's adaptation and extrapolation 36 years later...I'd say Villeneuve pulled off something amazing.

This is quite an atmospheric and engrossing film. There are some pretty decent visual effects/CGI present. Its obviously one of those films that leaves you wondering what is 'real' and what isn't. I thought the incidental music played lightly in the background was quite effective. It was nice seeing the flying cars again, as featured in the original film. I'm not sure if I ever really believe society could end up quite how its portrayed in films such as these, as soon as by 2049 but who knows?. This film certainly has a mysterious feel to it and decent performances from Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford. I felt it had a similar 'feel' to it as the Matrix films - I suppose the obvious similarities being that their science fiction films based in mainly CGI generated landscapes etc. It also made me think of the more recent Ghost in the Shell film with Scarlet Johansson.

This is certainly a decent sequel and so its worth a watch, yes - mainly if your comfortable with many scenes featuring little in the way of dialogue. The bright lighting/colours used emphasised the other-worldly or otherwise artificial nature of the settings featured.

The second Blade Runner is a long, at times rather slow, cyberpunk sci-fi movie, that has beautiful (sometimes practical) effects, that were absolutely beautiful to look at, but I thought, that Harrison Ford would be a major role, because the movie is advertised with that, but *spoiler* he appears the first time after 1h50. The cinematography knocks it out of the park, but behind that guise lies a decent main character and meh surrounding characters with a nice plot and the acting was good at times. But I had a hard time getting into this film, and I was left disappointed.

They had 40 years to follow in the footsteps of one of the greates science fiction movies of all times. And that's what they came up with? This is so mainstream, it's an insult to mainstream. It's not enough they just took some corner stones of the original,  a bad company boss, a dying replicant...no...father meets daughter, which is a daughter of rachel, that's pathetic, and please....what the hell is the fighting scene between harris an gossling? Yes, the movie is cinematic. But that doesn't make up for a shallow follow up. I would have left the cinema half way through, but I was sitting on the balcony and I would have disturbed the other guests, so I sat through that desaster. I wish I had bought the DVD instead of going to the cinema, at least I would have had the satisfaction to dump it in the bin.

To my mind this movie is even better than the original Blade Runner. "K" is introduced as a bounty hunter of sorts, but someone who is also an excellent detective. He is "constant K" - no emotion, all intellect. But we discover that he has been given a memory - one intended to give him more human responses in dealing with humans. That memory, and the events during the movie, result in "K" behaving in a way that represents the best of humanity - sacrifice for a greater cause.  Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford are superb in this movie, and the cinematography is amazing.  Definitely watch it several times. The day before yesterday, I watched one of the most acclaimed and philosophical sci-fi movies of all time: "Blade Runner". 35 years later, Denis Villeneuve (Ridley Scott this time was executive producer only) directed a sequel that gets two rare achievements: first, it maintains the original's essence, expands its universe, and the protagonist is as charismatic as Rick Deckard and it's not swallowed by him when both are on screen; and second, IT SURPASSES THE ORIGINAL! If the 1982 film was philosophical, this one is PHILOSOPHICAL with capital letters and maybe bold. While in that film we followed a journey of self-discovery of a supporting character, here we follow the protagonist's journey of self-discovery; he's actually solving two cases: the case that the LAPD assigned him (the external one) and the subsequent case that a piece of evidence put on his "mind" (the internal one). 30 years have been passed, it was incredible to see how the world has evolved and how the replicants have evolved; the dynamic between humans and replicants are completely different now, which impeded the screenwriters (the same of the 1982 film) to tell the same type of story. It's still an action/sci-fi movie, but they knew what made "Blade Runner" so special and invested in that sector. Ryan Gosling is perfect as K: inexpressive on the outside (he's a replicant after all), but as the film progresses, his emotions start to be de-bottled. Harrison Ford is a legendary actor and Rick Deckard is possibly his third most famous character, only behind Han Solo and Indiana Jones; Deckard's cold personality is maintained here, and Gosling proved how good he is by not being obfuscated by Ford's presence. Ana de Armas' character is by far the most intriguing: she, in personality, looks like Karen (Plankton's computer wife from "SpongeBob: SquarePants") but with a human body, and she's possibly the pivot of K's internal journey (alongside Mackenzie Davis). Dave Bautista and Jared Leto have little screen time but their characters aren't forgettable, Sylvia Hoeks is a cool and dangerous antagonist, and Robin Wright remembered me of Judi Dench's M from Daniel Craig's 007 franchise. The cinematography, soundtrack and sound work are DAZZLING; this movie is definitely a sensory experience, and I'm really jealous of those who watched this masterpiece in a movie theatre. Oh, and I still keep with my theory that Rick Deckard is a human.
Yes it was "visually stunning" (well somebody was stunned I guess) but a snooze fest.

In 2017, I was looking forward to seeing this movie hit the big screen. For whatever reason, I never got around to going out and seeing it - this was a major mistake. It would eventually hit Red Box and my wife and I checked it out. I was distracted while I watched it and didn't pay too much attention to the movie - this was a major mistake. Early in 2020, I decided to sit down and just watch the movie again by myself - this was a great decision! Dennis Villeneuve and Roger Deakins along with the superb cast, crew, and production team really did create a masterpiece here that deserves your undivided attention from start to finish. What's more, Hans Zimmer captured the atmosphere of the original Blade Runner film with his soundtrack, while creating something entirely new. I've probably watched this movie 30-40 times since 2020 and I have to apologize to Dennis for not seeing the movie in theaters as it was intended - I saw Dune twice to make up for it!!

This surely had the best cinematography of any movie I've seen, driven at least partially by the production design giving Deakins such aesthetically pleasing things to point his camera at. The mix of awe, appreciation and recognition that I was witnessing pure cinematic art is difficult to put into words. This franchise has by far the most intriguing backdrop of any movie I've ever seen and watching more plots unfold in it will be a joy if they go forward with their TV show or more movies. I feel especially sure of that because of how uninteresting I found this particular plot to be, a similar feeling I had to the first one. The incredible sense of magnitude and hidden depths and mystery that their impeccable setting offers led me to appreciate even less how ultra-low the plot's stakes were. I didn't agree that killing the replicants was necessary in the first place (at least in the context of the movie; I'm aware the novel is different) and tracking down the kid was just not a riveting premise for me. My opinion was reduced even further when they directly tied Deckard into it instead of just having him show up to help as it implies that in all of the gigantic cityscape the only two interesting things to have ever happened involved him. As with the first movie I feel I would appreciate this (which essentially serves as a requel) more if it began a franchise where better stories are told in the same universe.

A sequel as visually dazzling and thought-provoking as the original, this film truly stands as a momentous achievement in its own right. Firstly, Roger Deakins was very much deserving of the Oscar he won for cinematography. Each shot is museum worthy. And Villeneuve and the rest of the creative team brought to life again this dystopic vision of a cyberpunk future LA, and it remains enchanting. I also love the route they take with this story, centering on a Blade Runner who knows he is a replicant instead of rehashing the is-he-or-isn't-he question of Deckard from the first one. K's arc of slowly starting to believe that he is special only to find out that, in that one specific way, he is not was satisfyingly subversive. The parallelism of Luv, a replicant who also sees herself as special, is a great choice as well. Joi is another character that invites analysis, since we have to consider (as K does) if she was merely following her obvious AI programming to make K feel better or if she was able to reach some level of being a "real girl." As with the original, it is a slow movie that really demands your attention. And as with the original, I feel this is a film that requires multiple viewings to truly have seen it. Blade Runner 2049 (2017) directed by Denis Villeneuve.

Thirty years after the events of Blade Runner (1982), a new blade runner, Oficcer K ( Ryan Gosling) discovers one big secret about the replicants that could turn the world around and cause a revolution. His discovery leads him to find more about the truth and ends up finding Rick Deckard, a L.A.P.D. officer, who has been missing for 30 years.

Denis Villeneuve is a Sci-Fi master and was able to put together an incredible piece of art. With the help of one of the best cinematographers working right now, the incredible Roger Deakins, and the help of the amazing Han Zimmer, Denis was able to present us with this Masterpiece.

This movie is everything a sequel should be it picks up the universe it's predecessor created and expanded it and somehow also made it more interesting. It created great new characters, which we were able to connect with, and was able to bring elements from the past with sublteness and intelligence.

It takes it's time and it's the opposite of the majority of the modern Sci-Fi movies. Its pace paired with the astounishing shots and the groundbreaking score allows us to connect with everything in this universe, it captures us and makes us prisioners of that world for the runtime of 2 hours and 44 minutes.

The story unrolls in quite an unique way, it's like every inch of dialogue matters and you really don't want to miss anything, just for the pleasure of connecting the dots and being able to feel everything. I wasn't expecting to be hit in such an emotional level.

Ryan Gosling was definitly the best casting choice. He absolutely nailed the role. Ana de Armas was also amazing and portrayed the role of the A.I. Cyberpunk girlfriend with ease. Harisson as always was a fucking badass. Carla Juri with little screentime was able to do a really great job portraying Rachael and Rick's long lost daughter.

This is one of the most beautifully shot movies I've seen, every look, every landscape, every face, every shot felt like it should be there and carried a lot with it. Loneliness and the sense of getting lost have never been so well portrayed in a Sci-Fi movie.

This is everything modern Sci-Fi movies should be.

Thank you Denis for making this Masterpiece, thank you Ridley for creating this world. Would give everything to be able to watch this on the big screen.

Bladerunner or Bladebummer?

I really wanted to enjoy this film, I was even looking forward to
something a bit more mainstream after our obscurities, but one must be
careful what one wishes for and in the end I couldn't, it was just too
American.

All the mood lighting, bizarre decor and weird noises - just didn't work
for me. Although Scott's film had these in his it served to create a
believable, if alien, and atmospheric world. In this one it just served
to give the appearance of trying to convince idiotic Americans that
something significant or profound was going on. If an intelligent man
said they found this stylisation an original and artistic creation I
would believe him but for me, it was not that.

The characters too were often paper thin - the protagonist, with
designer stubble and bomber jacket come trenchcoat, being played as hard
boiled when he was obviously the prettiest boy in school, the hard
hitting ageing blond tom boy boss with greased back hair who swore a lot
and acted mean but in the end died for her employee, the sexy but deadly
evil assassin in tight trousers, the weird psycho in some bizarre
futuristic version of a lonely mansion having no idea what a fruitloop
he is whilst seemingly performing some of the world's most complex
scientific tasks with nothing more than a giant plastic bag, some slime
and a floating camera for tools - all a little bit cliche for me.

The dialogue didn't do any better which at it's absolute best was
sickeningly pseudo-philosophical with fake insight and dubious value.

That being said I did start to warm to the film a little, or perhaps
just got used to it, then they brought in Harry. It felt a little like
Luke Skywalker in the new Star Wars - these youngsters, actors and
directors, need to bring in the old hands to give what they are doing
some depth, what are they going to do when there are no more old hands?
But Harry did bring a little depth, but not enough and he could not
redeem the film.

The whole thing seemed like something that was created deliberately to
make money or make an impression but there seemed very little
originality or creativity in it, like a man making an unusual looking
cake but underneath is just a sponge to a tried and tested recipe, it
did not feel like an artist's individual and personal expression.
Perhaps it is the cinema version of contemporary art - pointless.

I have come down harsh and perhaps there were some good things about
this film. Although like usual far too much CGI ruined the visual
appearance and experience as a whole but it was moderately pretty in
places. I imagine the Yanks will love it, but in the end, like so many
films before, they should have just left Blade Runner alone.

Unfortunately in this day and age, many are unable to truly enjoy or even understand what long takes even mean and get bored.  The long spaces are not only like reading between the lines, but giving you room to imagine, easing into the replicant world as a participant and an inquirer.  As the future of AI intelligence and robotics is progressively growing at an exponential rate, this movie imagines a fragment of the possible consequences which inevitably influence economy, politics, societal hierarchies, when AI can become as intelligent and convincing as human beings at a certain point; perhaps even at a cellular level.

And the final speech by Roy was so damn good. The philosophical questions this movie brings are so deep and I think about it a lot. But, what I want to say is that 2049 does almost the same thing as Blade Runner but maybe even better. It is a philosophical film about how humans and A.i live together so normally that at a certain point, humanity will be no longer the "normal" breed that is accompanied by a captivating directing and soundtrack. It is an immersive experience that you need to live. The only problem of this sequel is that I felt a bit lost about the plot. I'm led to believe that this is the TV premiere of Blade Runner 2049, and that's why I'm flagging it up, as well as the fact that it is a truly astonishing piece of film making. But please, don't watch this on ITV2 if possible, buy yourself the blu-ray or stream it. At the very least watch it on ITV2HD. Roger Deakins' cinematography is a joy to behold, utterly captivating, and finally won him an Oscar at 467th attempt. Denis Villeneuve continues to craft brilliant film after brilliant film, and if his previous output is anything to go by, we should all be very excited about his vision of Dune, which is still currently slated for a Christmas release. No-one had any right to make a sequel to Blade Runner, but Villeneuve somehow takes the gauntlet and runs with it, managing to keep all the unanswered brain twisters still left to your own interpretations, and the way he keeps the story alive interspersing it with staggering world building is both a homage to the original, and very much earns the right to its own place in the Blade Runner universe. A staggering achievement.

Despite its length, Blade Runner 2049 manages to remain consistently enthralling thanks in part to its amazing visual spectacle. Blade Runner 2049 is a sequel that goes toe to toe with the original Blade Runner in terms of riveting visuals, atmosphere and memorable dialogue. The makers were wise enough to make the movie its own in terms of design and pacing, use sound and music in a creative way to hark back to the original and use CGI in a restrained and an unobtrusive way. Although the pacing is not as tight as the original the writing is not afraid to push this futuristic story into uncharted and disturbing territories. Like the original story the police are hunting synthetic humanoids, but with a plot twist- synthetic humans are killed if they are outdated in favor of newer more obedient models. The Blade Runner hunting the synthetic humans is himself a stronger, more resilient, more lethal and more observant synthetic human. All of this takes place in a dystopian view of the future where the cities are gray sprawling overpopulated over-polluted industrial wastelands devoid of any beauty. A new corporation has arisen producing ever more efficient and obedient synthetic humans headed by a creative industrialist. Given that the newer and more obedient synthetic humans are even more efficient killing machines than before the movie suggests in no uncertain terms that the fault lies eternally with humanity as a savage and immoral maker and not the creation. The main character in the movie, the synthetic human Blade Runner ‘K' also has a holographic female companion. The notion that artificial life will seek companionship from other artificial life forms seems strangely unsettling, as if it requires some sort of supervision or that the need for companionship is a unique trait restricted to humans. The need for a machine to have need for companionship also makes it appear as a drawback revealing an interesting assumption that we view machines as supposedly efficient, but not ourselves as machines or at least accept that we are ‘inefficient machines'. Whereas the original Blade Runner raised philosophical questions Blade Runner 2049 makes our transgressions and prejudices visceral and pushes them right in front of the audience.  Whether it is the slimy birth of a new synthetic model, children working in factories, intolerance for artificial life procreating or the dismissal of the illusion of free will underpinned by genetics, the movie doesn't pull punches. In his search for the offspring of Replicants the Blade Runner ‘K' navigates a hellscape of industrial excrement, but the most damning indictment is that humanity ultimately gave up on the real world and morality and lives in the ruins of past efforts to produce more and more tactile fantasies.

Short review: blade runner 2049 is a stunningly shot, well acted, and wonderfully complex film that wholeheartedly lives up to the original 
long review: Blade runner 2049 follows "k" (Ryan Gosling) a new age replicant who is tasked with hunting down and "retiring" older model replicant who have been deemed  illegal. but clues lead him to believe that he may be more than just a replicant... truthfully that is only about a quarter of the plot, but revealing any more would spoil the movie. watching this movie was a treat the whole way through. all the actors played their parts beautifully, especially Ryan Gosling and Ana de Armas. but possibly the best part of the about this movie is the cinematography. every shot is beautiful on its own, and when they are put together it becomes one of the most stunning movies that i have watched in a long time. another aspect of this film that i loved was the complex plot of the movie that only fits together at the very end. although this could confuse some of the less attentive viewers, it rewards everyone who pays attention to the screen. the plot is also incredibly character driven, which allows the almost every character in the movie to have a well thought out and detailed ark. that being said there was a couple small things i didn't care for as much. for example  there are 2 or 3 moments where a character has a realization and the movie flashes back to a previous scene. this slightly removed me from the immersion of the film. however, this is a small complaint about what is otherwise an incredible film.

It is longer than it should be. The positives are : The cinematography is the best I've ever seen in a film, every frame looks like a beautiful painting. The score by Hans Zimmer was incredible, kind of futuristic I loved it. Ryan Gosling is wonderful in this movie as was all of the cast. It had a great story and message about what it is and means to be human. Blade runner 2049 is one of my favourite movies, and it was my favourite movie of 2017!

Blade Runner 2049 starts off strong. Batista's brief cameo battling Ryan Gosling's ‘K' is a strong opening to the movie and I have the assumption from this we're in for an action packed sci-fi extravaganza. I'm pretty wrong here I'll admit it now. The pacing of this movie is a problem for me. After that strong start, I assume they're building plot and the story. They are but it seems to last for a very long time. Every single time I feel it's about to speed up the story slows back down again. I remained engaged throughout but that's only through a conscious effort rather than a gripping tale. 

Look the premise for this movie is awesome. Even without seeing the first I love the idea of these artificial slaves having hope and a way of breaking their oppression. The movie just never speeds up even at the end of the film I'm left underwhelmed and a little disappointed. There's a few good moments but not any that blow me away. 

The draw for this movie for me is the incredible visual demonstration we get. The film is beautifully put together and it literally jumps off the screen. I kind of wish I saw this at the cinema just to see how this came out on the big screen. I can imagine it was unreal. No matter how stunning the film is though it never blows my mind away just my eyes. 

This film is fully advertised as being a combo of Ford and Gosling being the joint leads. The thing is though Ford doesn't turn up until an hour 45 into the film. He's only in it for the last hour and even then is not shown a great amount. The same with Jared Leto he's one of our main villains but he's barely shown and when he's on screen I find him a really dull character. 

The star here is Gosling. He's absolutely brilliant as ‘K' whose on his journey of self discovery and is breaking out of the way he's programmed. He goes on a great journey throughout the film and this is really his film and nobody else's. He's a brilliant action star and that's not something we see regularly from him. It's just a shame this film didn't have a bit more action for him to be involved in. If it did then my rating would have been much higher.

Blade Runner 2049 is honestly a masterpiece and a half, the movie's got a great story.

The story is pretty much about this lad called Officer K (Ryan Gosling) who's an officer with the Los Angeles police department, he finds out a big secret which could end up starting lots of chaos.

He later goes on a mission to find a former blade runner called Deckard (Harrison Ford) who's been missing for the past three decades.

The acting from all of the cast throughout this movie is honestly brilliant, especially from Ryan Gosling and Harrison Ford, those two are honestly amazing in this movie.

The dialogue which is given throughout this movie is honestly brilliant, the dialogue never feels too forced. It just feels very natural and it's really well given from all of the characters who are in this movie.

Also, the chemistry between Officer K and Deckard is great and it's built up so well throughout this movie.

The movie's even got some beautiful music composed by Hans Zimmer, Benjamin Wallfisch, Ron Bartlett and Michael Hodges. Those four do a great job on composing this beautiful soundtrack as a whole.

The pacing throughout this movie is honestly great and each moment is built up very well.

The cinematography from the man, the myth and the legend Roger Deakins is honestly so beautiful. He captures the scenes so beautifully and he does such a great job at capturing the moments so well.

Finally, the action sequences throughout this movie are very clever and very graphic and they're also very well done.

The CGI effects hold up pretty well and they don't look very outdated at all, which is really good.

The green screen effects throughout this movie also hold up very well and they're very aesthetically pleasing to look at.

The movie's even got some great visuals which also hold up very well and they have such a unique look to them.

The set designs for this movie have a very beautiful and unique look to them, which I thought made them look very unique.

Overall, Blade Runner 2049 is honestly a masterpiece and a half. The movie's got a great story, brilliant acting, brilliant dialogue, great chemistry, beautiful score, great pacing and some beautiful cinematography.

The movie's even got some very graphic action sequences, great CGI effects, aesthetically pleasing greenscreen effects, great visuals and some very beautiful set designs. 

I'd honestly recommend to watch this movie straight after watching the original Blade Runner (1982) it's honestly worth the watch.

This movie is visually stunning. It has a deep meaning. It shows a glimpse of a possible future. 
 Some movie critics criticize the movie for being over budget. They ask why it was necessary to spend $150 million on the movie when they should have known it would not do that well at the box office.  (same as the original Bladerunner).  What these accountants don't tell you is that you can't put a price on a work of art. This movie is a work of art. A work of art costs what it costs to make it. You can't cut corners when making art.   If you ask Picasso or Michelangelo to use cheaper paints, don't expect the same appearance in their finished product.  
 Yes, I am calling this movie a work of art - the highest praise I can give a movie. A work of art is something that I believe will last for decades at least.  It has a soul, an inner life. It is more than the sum of its parts. 
 Before I close I will say one thing that is avoided by almost every review then I've read. The dialogue in this movie is amazing. There is not one line or even one word that is unnecessary. Everything that is said either advances the storyline or explains something.  Gosling asks Ford about a dog, "Is he real?". Harrison Ford could say, yes, no, or I don't know. Instead, he answers, "Ask him yourself".
So, crank up the projector in your man-cave or  bedroom TV., and make sure you have a good supply of snacks because the movie runs almost 3 hours including credits. Tempus Fugit when you're having fun!

An entertaining and more expansive follow-up, combined with Villeneuve's direction, Fancher and Green's script, the performances of the cast, Zimmer and Wallfisch's score, Deakins' cinematography, Walker's editing, Gassner's production design, Querzola and Sipos's set decoration, April's costume design, action sequences and visual effects, Blade Runner 2049 expands its predecessor's story beautifully!!!
This movie was so good that it could have been a stand alone film if the first movie didn't exist.

Though I think what is the hardest sell is Ryan Gosling's character.  In the first movie we seen a passionate lead character in with Ford.  He was hot tempered, impulsive, frustratingly doing the cold and dirty work of retiring replicants.  Gosling's character was more stoic and hard to connect with, which offered little diversions from the main plot (who's the replicants)

Blade Runner 2049 manages to build upon the original film, along with telling its own story in a wonderful way. If you are a fan of the original, you will most likely enjoy this film. However, for most of the modern audience, the movie is seen as too slow. As someone who thoroughly enjoyed the original, I was looking forward to watching this. I was not disappointed... for the most part. Aesthetically, the film looks absolutely stunning. Roger Deakins, who also did the cinematography for 1917, did an amazing job with Blade Runner 2049. I was even so amazed that I was sometimes distracted from the movie itself, which is a problem, I suppose. The story is somewhat similar to the original, asking the same questions, but it also adds the new element of replicas giving birth. This new fact has the potential to start a war, without giving too much away, the plot finishes in a very pleasing way. However, I did find that although Ryan Gosling is a great actor, he felt really stiff in this movie. More stiff than Harrison Ford, and that's saying something. The dialogue was also quite weak at times, but again, visually, it's absolutely amazing. I could honestly pick any frame of this as a background, and it would work. It is really a piece of art in that sense. The way that it merges the old and the new kind of reminds me of The Force Awakens, but in a way, I do think that this movie is better. I love this movie in so many ways, it looks amazing and asks some interesting questions, however, the script is sometimes dull and Ryan Gosling is stiff. But still, it's a wonderful thought provoking film that I would recommend, 8.2/10

This movie underperformed at the box office for one reason:  It is WAY TOO SMART for  mainstream audiences.  And, yes, that is a commentary on the younger generation, which makes up a majority of today's moviegoers.  Young people today just want to check their brains at the door and be entertained, but "Blade Runner 2049" won't let them do that--It's a movie for intelligent people, and there just aren't a lot of those around nowadays.  Personally, I think "2049" is even better than the original "Blade Runner" (which I think is a tad bit overrated) and might possibly be one of the best science fiction sequels in the history of movies, right up there with "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Aliens".   Some scenes do drag on a bit too long, and that's the only reason I can't give it a full five stars.  But for 90% of the movie's length, I was riveted to the screen.

 Blade Runner 2049  takes everything that makes the original great and runs with it. It continues the narrative of  What does it mean to be Human?  without using the first film as a crutch (Like  The Force Awakens ). The story is so unique and intriguing.

All the characters are developed perfectly. The script is wonderful and every actor does such a great job in their role. Every character plays their role in the narrative. Officer K is a Replicant trying to be human. Joi is a program who wants to feel. Wallace and Luv are the oppressing forces acting in self interest. Deckard is a human trying to protect those he loves.

While the cult status of the original may have hardened the hearts of longtime fans, preventing them from even considering whether 2049 could approach its predecessor, Iñárritu's sweeping visuals are a sumptuous feast for the eyes that should convert even diehard fans. Likewise, the narrative expands on Scott's production in a way that only serves to enhance that of the original, expanding its universe while producing a compelling independent narrative. (4.5/5)

What kind of sci-fi film would Jesus make? We'll leave that to the Thumpers and the Trumpsters, but maybe this one is to the New Testament as the original "Blade Runner" is to Genesis—though the latter remains the undisputed masterpiece. BR2049 is thoroughbred Blade Runner, though, seamlessly flowing from its progenitor to expand the narrative to deeper, richer and visually stunning themes and a moodier melancholy. The retrofitted future comes with updates: what more could a lonely Blade Runner want than a beautiful sentient holographic wife who can sync with real prostitutes? The rainy city's streets are still dominated by everything Japanese (although Ryan Gosling's anti-gravity car is a Peugeot, of all things). But more to the point: like a leisurely swim in a warm pool, you'll find yourself luxuriating in philosophical and sociopolitical themes of corporate Big Brother, life and death, existential angst, what's real and what's not. Do androids dream of electric sheep?

Tonally very different to Blade Runner but spiritually very similar. It's a magnetic film, a brisk film despite its running time, it deepens and widens the world and does the impossible; tells an interesting and different follow up, intrinsically linked to the first film but yet it's own yarn. It takes a thread about memory and it makes it it's focus. A worthy and artistic sequel and maybe the most beautiful and visually accomplished film since the first one. Consistently high quality, and a few blips aside, it's a pretty excellent film by all accounts.

Very delicately it examines memory, artifices of love and devotion, expectation and duty, cause and belief. It deftly dresses a twist in a twist and plays with many of the themes inside the film and out. Long, messy, obfuscating with glaring holes in it, but also painterly to look at, trippy, hallucinatory, tender. It rises above its flaws and produces not just a perfect sequel but a tremendous, thoughtful, elegant science fiction masterpiece.

If the original film had any loose ends (which is debatable), they flap about for three hours here, until assuming their final positions with some well judged twists along the way. And don't get me wrong, the twists are good.

But we don't watch Blade Runner for twists; we want a surprising future to reveal itself, and as a sequel it can't play that card again. It becomes more about memory than ever: memories of memories (such as the holograms of his lost love or of Elvis); memories of other people's memories (driving the characters); and our own memory of the first film.

Because of this reference to our own memories, the film is somewhat stuck to its prequel, and though this involves us intimately, it's not always in a good way. It breaks the fourth wall by constantly reminding us that we're watching a movie.

Here we also see the phenomenon of how sequels are strait jacketed by the premises set down in the original. This always risks a slight block to creativity, and belabouring once fresh ideas, and worst of all, narrows the corridors and shrinks the maze in which the writers can roam.

If the majestic pace of the original was supported by Vangelis's heavy score, this one drags somewhat with less air in the musical balloon to haul it along. Not one theme is memorable, and the whole score sounds like a bad pastiche.

Suffused with yellow light and wonderful performances, there is gold to be found here, literally, but nowhere near the treasure of the original.

'Blade Runner 2049' is the sequel that Ridley Scotts underappreciated 1984 masterpiece deserved. Its methodic, stoic and probably one of they must well shot films in recent time. Denis Villeneuve takes his time with his shots and lets the film unfold slowly. The twists and turns are layed out one after the other perfectly. Gosling plays a conflicted replicant blade runner who struggles throughout the film with the levity of the situation but in the end understanding that he is simply another cog in the works, a silent hero. Harrison Ford shows up and plays an old Rick Deckard excellently giving us a grisled performance. The orginal Blade Runner asked the question what makes us human? And 2049 continues that theme improving on the concept. Villeneuve shows us that in such a bleak world the lines are blured between humans and replicants and that its the idea of connection that makes us human.

I became very cautious at the idea of a sequel being made over thirty years after the first film's release. But 2049 understands everything that made its predecessor a classic. The sequel introduces new routes of discussion to the original's themes of humanity, artificial intelligence, class division, and so much more. Most of the characters are new and interesting additions to the series while the ones that return are treated with respect and feel at home in this new movie. The visuals in this film are just as breathtaking today as the original Blade Runner was for audiences back in the '80s.

Thirty years after the events of the first movie, Blade Runner 2049 follows the story of replicant K (Ryan Gosling) who unearths a secret that could rock the world to its core. I remember watching this for the first time and scoring it high 90's. While I still think it's a damn good movie, I feel it falls just out of Masterpiece range.

Acting: 10
Gosling was stellar in his performance as K. Replicants walk the line of being human, but robotic at the same time. In some cases Gosling provides responses that are straight out of the mouth of a program while there are some scenes that require him to capture raw emotion, both unexpected and welcomed by me as a viewer. There were some other memorable performances as well, particularly by Sylvia Hoeks in her role as Luv. I'll be honest, she frightened the hell out of me, but in a good way. She was calculated and controlled, but you could always sense a rage waiting to surface. I love what she did with this character.

Beginning: 10
The opening scene of this movie sees K tracking down a replicant that's been trying to fly under the radar. The tension is built slowly before it bubbles over. In the climax of this scene, we get a taste of what is to come for the rest of the movie. That's what beginnings are all about: Leave us wanting more!

Characters: 10

Cinematography/Visuals: 10
While the entire film as a whole may not qualify as a masterpiece, the visuals and cinematography most certainly are. Throughout the movie, you get a chique futuristic feel that's also dreary and dank at the same time. It's like you're watching two worlds collide. I love their play on robotics and weaponry here as well, definitely a step up from the first film.

Conflict: 10
It's not just about the action here, but also K unravelling a mystery before our eyes. You want him to get to the bottom of everything going on and you're taken on a wild ride along the way. Between the shootouts with hi-tech guns and the hand-to-hand fights, there is more than enough to keep you entertained. 

My favorite scene in particular occurs when K and Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford) meet for the first time and square off. They are in some kind of concert hall where holograms are performing. Both are relying on the singing of the holograms to improve their striking position. It really is fun to watch.

Entertainment Value: 9
It doesn't take you long into this movie to realize you're watching something special. The time and energy that went into the creation of this movie shows up on screen. Yes, it could have been shortened, but I still had a great experience.

Memorability: 10
There is a scene that sticks out in my head where replicant creator Niander Wallace (Jared Leto) is looking over one of his creations. It's unsettling to put it lightly and you feel like it's just an average monologue…until it's not. There are a number of scenes just like this that press on my brain. I also loved the continued exploration from the last movie of what it means to be human.

Pace: 8
I do appreciate that the story took its time to unfold. However, I do feel like it could have been a smidge faster in spots. There were a few moments where I was thinking, "Man, I got things to do! Let's go!" Mostly forgivable save for a few instances.

Plot: 10

Resolution: 1
Without giving anything away, I will just say that this is my least favorite part of the movie. To have started so strong only to end like this? Not impressed. I wanted more for K is all I will say.

Overall: 88
There's nothing like good sci-fi when done well. Blade Runner 2049 will take you on highs and lows while giving you a visual feast in the process. I was not disappointed in the least and you won't be either.

This is what sci-fi is all about. There are so many layers to this beautifully rendered masterpiece that it begs re-watching almost immediately. The film falls into none of the traps other sci-fi sequels do and when the character of Deckard is reintroduced Harrison totally re-creates a seamless performance from the first installment. All other performances are first class and worthy of a place in sci-fi history.

Denis Villeneuve had a near impossible task in producing a worthy sequel to one of the greatest films of all time Blade Runner (1982) and miraculously he does. Despite casting Ryan Gosling, the Harrison Ford of his day, in the lead when he could have picked a more interesting character screenwriters Hampton Fancher and Michael Green populate the film with fascinating characters like Luv and Niander Wallace. The film is almost as beautiful as it's predecessor and contains action scenes that equal the pursuit of Zhora while continuing the exploration of the philosophical questions asked in the first film. I had high expectations going in and I was on cloud nine for the rest of the week having had all of my expectations met.

Thirty years after the events of Blade Runner, â~blade runner' K, Ryan Gosling, discovers that replicants can sexually reproduce and is told by his commanding officer lieutenant Joshi, Robin Wright, to retire the offspring of Rachael. Meanwhile, Niander Wallace, Jared Leto, the successor to Tyrell sends replicant Luv, Sylvia Hoeks, to steal the remains of Rachael, the replicant who reproduced, so that he can use them for his own nefarious means. K, a replicant himself, comes to believe that he is Rachael's child when his memories match up to information he finds. As in the first film, there is a climactic showdown between hero and villain where the lines become blurred and philosophical questions are pondered.

By far the best aspect of the film is the exploration of Luv's character because she is the most emotionally affecting in the film. Her desire to her prove herself to her near psychopathic father Niander is never more clear than at the moment at which the body of a fellow replicant is carelessly disposed of as we see a single tear trickle down her otherwise placid face. Her physical abilities are also impressive as she is able to match K in their final fight and when she confidently states "I am the best one" I felt the sort of excitement I have only ever felt at the end of Krzysztof Kieslowski movies. She was emotionally complex and it was fun to watch her fight the male lead, what more could you want from the female lead in a Blade Runner sequel?

Although I would not consider Harrison Ford to be a great actor and I felt the lack of development in the relationship between Rachael and Deckard was one of the few flaws of the first film their relationship produced one of the most emotional moments in the film. When Deckard stares at a hologram of Rachael and is tested on his response he responds tearfully "I know what I felt" as he recognizes that the hologram can not replicate the feelings he had for the Rachael he knew. Ford is surprisingly able to sell the seen as we see a man who cemented himself as a gruff action star give himself over to the emotion of love as the awe in his eyes as the woman he loves touches him again is beautiful and touching. Had Blade Runner dealt with the love story better this scene would have been even more affecting but this scene does a great job at making up time on the predecessor's poor treatment of Rachael and forces you to care.

Of the many, many wonderful things about this film the cinematography is obviously high up on the list as Roger Deakins, returning from the first film, does some of his best work. There is the beautiful orange sheen present in most Deakins film present here but even more so as the Wallace corporation complex is absurdly colorized and reflections of flowing water appear on the walls. Each shot could be framed and put up on my wall, even those of Harrison Ford's confused face, with the exterior shots in particular feeling like worthy successors to the iconic Coca-Cola commercials of the first film.

Blade Runner 2045 was honestly the best movie I saw in 2018. There is a distinguishable difference between Blade Runner and the rest of the garbage I've seen this year: theme, purpose. The narrative of Blade Runner never fell short of amazing other than Jared Leto's pointless character (and he can be easily overlooked). The pacing feels like a wave that you can watch building on the horizon until its finally on you and you don't know what hit you; There is tension and meaning behind its speed. Speaking of waves, there is actually a scene in the movie where Hans Zimmer's music matches with the action to make you feel like drowning in waves.... so much cinematic innovation. The purpose and theme of this story manifests in every second of the film (as opposed to the tangents that so many blockbuster films descend into.) I thought this was almost a perfect movie. It messes with you and shows you what the fire of honor looks like in a realm of torrential rain.

The year is 2049, there is the real world and the outer world, separated by a wall, presumably built by America and paid for by Mexico. Global warming has not been kind; LA is in the year of winter powered by the perpetually sunny state of California which has been covered in stunning solar panel towers. There is a shortage of crops but we still have cigarettes as tobacco fields are both an important part of American GDP and a great way to make someone look bad ass in the movies.

If this film is in any way a prediction of the future it's good to know that technology gets way out of hand, also buy Mitsubishi shares now, diversify portfolio with Coca-Cola and sex bots.

On a side note I once read that after Return Of The Jedi, George Lucas held back on making any more Star Wars movies until the technology was right. That might also be fitting of Blade Runner. The film just can't fail to disappoint, visually it's stunning, with its vast landscapes, baron city ruins, fallout zones, mega cities, and technological fantasy.

Blade Runner also captures a complex and obscure dystopian future featuring child slavery, android servitude, and a macho world of sexual obscenity not too dissimilar to Duke Nukem's Land Of The Babes. Technologically there is a lot to take in, from the delights of hover cars to mainstream JOI companionship, in 2049 Joi is a robot hologram who will risk everything in the pursuit of syphilis. One bit of technology that stood out was the 4D TV's, I mention as Back To The Future also predicted them so I'm thinking it's only a matter of time folks.

The plot is enjoyable, it neatly works on its predecessor's mind melt that people can't guarantee that they're human because memories are implanted faster than the NSA can access your webcam but it adds a twist with Replicants urging to be recognised as equals, and you get the sense that the Replicants are gearing up for a Hunger Games style conflict sooner or later.

The Replicant's call to war comes with the discovery of a child born of Replicant descent. So basically this is the plot from Orphan Black, a child born from a clone gets hunted down by an evil corporation so that they can do testing on its genetic structure or something.

However unlike Orphan Black there is less logic behind the corporations motivations to recover the child, for instance if they really wanted to produce well behaved drones then reproduction might not be the best way of doing it, on the premise that you have more genetic uncertainties and less control over production and data analysis.  Also it seems as if Mr Wallace has created a technology which has garnered him huge wealth and he's left looking a bit like a one dimensional super villain suffering from a god complex, with very weak motivations and a lack of depth. 

Ms Luv also fails to use the company's firepower to wipe out K which makes it feel a bit like a weak Bond movie at times because you never feel like he is in critical danger and the one question you come away with is why at any point in this movie wasn't K killed when he could have been.

The LAPD leader is like the love child of Theresa May and Mariano Rajoy and her motivations to quell rebellion before it kicks off a referendum are a bit easier to understand. This makes the plot a bit more tangible and if the corporations motivations were a bit meatier this film would have a more complete feel about it.

Blade Runner also attempts to raise familiar questions in AI SciFi such as when is an android considered equal to a human, when does AI start to think for itself, can AI feel real emotion and if so does such emotion relate to independent thought. With that in mind, despite the weak plot points, Blade Runner offers total escapism into a bizarre world, worth seeing for the innovative technologies, abstract ideas and stunning landscapes.
A complete tribute to the original material source. A triumph for Denis Villeneuve.

Blade Runner 2049 is a sequel to Ridley Scott's ambitious sci-fi movie Blade Runner. It's directed by Denis Villeneuve and Stars Ryan Gosling as Officer K and Harrison Ford as Rick Deckard. This movie reminds me why I love the art of film. Its colors and setting is gorgeous and truly feels like a dystopian Earth. It has a wonderful story that keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time and keeps you asking questions. The score is fantastic, the props are realistic, the costume choices were perfect, I mean this whole movie is as close to perfect as possible. In the film, we learn that Rick Deckard had a child with a replicant and is now being hunted by Blade Runners to find out how and to disclose this information from the public. Agent K is considered the worst kind of "person" because he is replicant who's job is to kill other replicants. Agent K is forced to go after Deckard while he is struggling to figure out if he is actually human. I'm not going to spoil the rest because I feel that anyone who loves movies should go watch this film. As I said with the first one It's pure Ridley Scott magic.

Blade Runner 2049 is a perfect example of why I love films.

This movie is beautiful in every aspect. The cinematography, the soundtrack, the visuals, the performances. Blade Runner 2049 is more than just a film, it is art perfected.

I liked the original Blade Runner, but I had some issues with it. The characters weren't multidimensional, and the story was lackluster. Some of the performances were questionable.

Blade Runner 2049 improves upon not only the amazing parts of the original, but fills in the gaps where it was lacking.

Whether it be a better script or the experience of age, I also felt that Harrison Ford's performance in this film was far superior to that of the original Blade Runner.

K (Ryan Gosling) is a complex and interesting character. By revealing K to be a Replicant immediately, the film is able to explore the deeper nuances of what it truly means to be human. K's relationship with Joi (Ana de Armas) is heartfelt and meaningful. I've seldom experienced such devastation in a film as I did the moment when Luv (Sylvia Hoeks) crushed Joi out of existence.

I could continue to gush eloquently about how amazing the world-building is and how immersive the soundtrack is, and how so much of this film's beauty lies below the surface... but it would become repetitious.

Suffice to say that if you haven't seen Blade Runner 2049 yet, stop what you're doing and watch it.

Where on earth do I start.  I'm sure that many people on here must have received some secret drug before entering the cinema as this has got to be one of the biggest let downs this year.  Every single scene is either a long meandering multi angled journey that in real life would take seconds, but in this takes at least ten minutes to show you how the scene looks from above, the side, the ground, the protagonist, the thing the protagonist is walking towards, the thing in the thing the protagonist is walking towards, a person who might be walking around watching the protagonist walking towards the thing in the thing he wants but really this person walking around watching isn't there at all, to then move to the protagonist holding the thing, turning the thing, studying the thing...or a close up of Ryan Gosling's face as he thinks, Hmmmmm, or gets annoyed, or gets sad, while randomly interspersed with other actors giving him cues to look confused or sad or....you get the point.
What seems to constitute good movie making now seemingly means making every scene as long as possible and only progressing a tiny proportion of the story while at the same time being as predictable as an ice cube on a hot plate.
