So where could they possibly take the Blade Runner franchise after the one-and-done original? Even as 2049 began, I had no idea, but somehow it manages not only to build on the original, develop the story naturally, and evolve it's themes, but sometimes even surpasses them. Replicants have had a rocky history in the last thirty years, being prohibited and brought back gradually after a series of violent outbursts. The Tyrell corp was bought out, there was a blackout that wiped out electronic records across the globe, and even a famine.

Sapper Morton benefitted from the famine with his protein farm, living a secluded life away from the dystopian hustle-and-bustle of LA. Until the day K arrives to bring him in, unraveling a miracle impossible to believe that could shake the very foundations of human society if the truth ever got out. To say more would potentially ruin the movie. I went in relatively blind and the mystery that surrounds the whole thing - the origins and revelations of each individual character - gave me so much joy to watch unfold. However, take this as your warning, I wouldn't be able to write the review I'd want to write without spoiling some pretty major stuff, so stop reading now.

The single biggest theme of both the original and 2049 is what it means to be human, what it means to be alive, how to measure consciousness and sentience, and whether that offers certain rights or not. 2049 builds on that, introducing new concepts with the express purpose of exploring and extrapolating this theme further. K is stated outright from the very beginning that he is a replicant. It's important information as he plays into how he's treated, and how he thinks of himself. While he thinks for himself, he is programmed to obey, and yet that doesn't make him come across as any less human. He's still treated as a lesser-class citizen because of it though, the same way white supremacists treat black people, or Myanmar Buddhists treat the Rohingya. One party sees themself as more important, as more real, and spit on those who they see as beneath them. K is at the bottom of the heap...to a point.

The most fascinating exploration of this theme in 2049 for me though was the character of Joi. She's a black box on K's wall, an evolved form of Amazon Echo and smart homes. She's an artificial prostitute without the sexual contact. For K, she's he's only companion, his best friend, his confidant. Strictly speaking she's an AI with holographic representation and nothing more, and yet she demonstrates more. She passes the Turing test with flying colours, convincing as a sentience all her own, with her own beliefs, her own desires, her own fears, her own personality. When K "gifts" her an emanator so she can leave his apartment and become mobile, she shows genuine delight and wonder at experiencing rain and watching it drop through her holographic fingers. And yet other replicants treat her with disdain. She's artificial companionship, a lesser being who's even less real than they are. It's a truly fascinating angle injected into the movie.

Another fantastic part of 2049's story is the use and subversion of the 'chosen one' trope. Final warning for MASSIVE SPOILERS here. As the underlying mystery unravels, K starts to believe he is the key to it all. He's about the right age, with a memory that connects him to orphanage records. As the movie goes on, both K and us - the audience - are increasingly led to believe that he is more than just a replicant. He's a special case with the key to everything. We watch him develop from nothing special, to the key to everything, before one final twist that causes this belief in himself to come crashing down around him and he just becomes nothing special again. It's an unprecedented character arc that subverts expectations in the best way. Even after he learns the truth, that he is nothing special, that Joi is just an AI product that told him everything he wanted to hear, he turns himself into something special. He risks his neck for a man he now has no connection to. He picks a side, embraces his heroism and goes for it hell for leather. After learning he wasn't special after all, he goes out and makes himself special, the hero of the story. If nothing else, that is what makes 2049 such a captivating story.

But there is something else. There's so much in 2049 to unpack, and I want to talk about all of it. Chief amongst them is the cinematography. Roger Deakins is Hollywood's biggest awards underdog. His work is simply astounding time and time again, and 2049 is no exception. Every frame is a canvas to him, as he paints glorious strokes of colour and composition. Every scene outside is grey and miserable, with snow falling peacefully around, and the streets covered in sludge. Everywhere looks like a miserable place to be, whether it's LA's slums, or the rubbish tip that is San Diego, or Morton's maggot farm that resembles a moonbase. The opening shots of the film show fields that stretch as far as the eye can see, bringing them into focus as warehouses, hangars, and industrial greenhouses. Wallace's headquarters tower above the iconic Tyrell pyramid, made of the wealthiest commodity; wood, while Deckard hides out in the irradiated wasteland of Las Vegas, bathed in red and orange hues.

The soundtrack is a bit of a mixed bag for me. I was disappointed to hear that Johann Johannsson had stepped down from scoring this film, as his work in Arrival was exquisite. Hans Zimmer stepping in was a bit meh. While he's strictly a fantastic film composer, his more recent works have felt phoned in (barring Dunkirk, of course). Another source of immediate disappointment was how little 80s influence there seemed to be. There's the odd synth here or there just peaking out from the cacophony, but otherwise it does little to try and emulate the sound of Vangelis. Furthermore, the soundscapes and ambience that permeates most scenes don't exactly sound like they're beyond Johannsson's skill set. It's the exact same kind of music he scored for Arrival and Sicario.

That said, what Hans Zimmer and Ben Wallfisch have crafted is still an amazing piece of sonic work. It's an auditory experience felt as much as it is heard, and it brings so much intensity to scenes that would be otherwise lacking. The music never takes the limelight or overstays it's welcome. It's a presence whose impact is felt even when the movie is silent. In fact the sound design in general is just about perfect, adding a whole new dimension to the film, including a fantastic sequence in a vintage casino with Elvis holograms that cut in and out suddenly.

The acting is also top-notch as well, of course. Ryan Gosling has become famous for his unblinking stares, some of which speak volumes with little surface emotion, while some falls flat and just looks lazy. I saw a video that took the piss out of his blank-faced expressions in the trailer, which was funny and kind of true, but having watched the movie, his lack of facial emoting makes sense. He's a replicant after all. Strictly speaking he doesn't, or at least shouldn't, have emotional responses. He's a blank slate stuck into the world to do one job and one job only. Thankfully the enthralling character arc allows Gosling some room to work, and the emotions he does realise are fully formed and fully empathising.

A big mention goes to Harrison Ford as well, who's turned himself into a bit of a meme in his old age, reviving old franchises and lazing through every scene as if he doesn't really want to be there. 2049 is an exception to the rule. He doesn't go into this for the paycheck, he has a genuine interest in the film, it's source material, and the script that was written for it. He offers his best performance in years, without a doubt, and creates all the impact of the final scene all by himself. Ana de Armas is also really, really good as Joi, giving her a sense of humanity and sentience that quite literally brings her to life. The chemistry she and Gosling share is palpable and goes a long way to developing her role as a non-sexual companion. Sylvia Hoeks is menacing as Luv, Wallace's right-hand assistant. While she doesn't get quite as much meat to play around with, she does have her interesting moments tapping into what it means to be an artificial sentience. The way she treats Joi is heartbreaking, and her snarky posture makes her just as human as her protagonistic opposites.

Jared Leto, Robin Wright, Edward James Olmos, Dave Bautista, Mackenzie Davis, Lennie James, Barkhad Abdi, and even a brief appearance from Sean Young all share varying levels of supporting roles, and all enhance the movie in their own little way. Whether it's Wright's subtle advances on K, Bautista's marvel at the miracle he witnessed decades ago, James' quick change of character when he realises K is a cop, or Leto's menacing philosophical musings, each of them make their mark on the movie in such a way that they'd be missed if they weren't there, whether they have two minutes of screen time or fifteen.

Finally I want to mention the CGI, which is used brilliantly. Just like the scoring, it's never overbearing and never steals the limelight. It's used to enhance and not to create all by itself. The vast dystopian vistas would be nothing without CGI, Joi's holographic representation would be nothing without it, and Sean Young being de-aged was a narrative necessity. On the note of Joi's holographic representation though, one of the finest displays of 2049's CGI is a beautifully tender scene between her, K, and Mariette, a prostitute who's tasked with shadowing him. Seeing as Joi is only holographic, K cannot physically interact with her in the way either of them desire to, and so Mariette becomes a surrogate. The way Joi merges with Mariette, and they sync up together and bleed in and out of each other's movements is just about one of the most impressive things I've seen for a long time. The way it's somehow kept from turning creepy or weird, and instead remains tender and beautiful is all the more impressive.

Could 2049 hit a perfect 10/10 rating? I don't think so, but I don't rate anything that well on a first or even second viewing. It has a hell of a lot going for it, from the way it balances nostalgia and self-referentialism to enhancing the story and themes of the original without retreading old ground is probably the best thing about it. But the story it tells and how it wants to tell it is executed to perfection. I have no doubt that in future, if I fancy watching Blade Runner, I'll choose 2049 over the original. Despite being slow and really quite long, it uses every moment to it's favour, building character and atmosphere perfectly. I give 2049 a 9/10, without hesitation. I already want to go to the cinema and watch it again.

If you thought Deckard (Harrison Ford) was the most interesting character from the original film then you will likely enjoy this version. On the other hand if you thought either Rachael (Sean Young) or Roy Batty (Rutger Hauer) was the most interesting character in the original film then you will likely feel disappointed here.

I can't emphasize how poor this script is in quality of writing. There isn't a single speech worthy of Roy Batty's "I've seen things you people wouldn't believe..." 

We also never get a memorable quote like Rachael's "Have you ever retired a human by mistake?" when she first meets Deckard, something that cuts to the heart of the issue of being human vs. android. Ryan Gosling is fine in the lead but his character seemed to have been rehashed entirely from "Drive" and transplanted into Villeneuve's overwhelmingly depressive universe. The villain was also poorly conceived and thoroughly unbalanced to care about. He's a pale imitation of Tyrell. 

I also found the music in Blade Runner 2049 to be inadequate. It's only similarity to the original is that it is electronica, otherwise it is depressingly dark, overbearingly loud, and without respite. It misses the mark of the brilliant Vangelis soundtrack of the original which mixed a futuristic melancholic cocktail. 

Denis Villeneuve is an eccentric but inconsistent filmmaker who needs scriptwriters who can match his vision. Blade Runner 2049 rests on the razor's edge of pass/fail.
